Conspiracy Theorists Suggest Katy Perry Is Really JonBenét Ramsey
=================================================================
!
**Photo: Photo: Randall Simons/Polaris.**
I can remember a period in the mid-'90s when my mom forbade me from looking at the magazines in the grocery store checkout. They were plastered with pictures of a little girl around my age, whose bright blue eyes and bouncy blonde curls were so perfectly doll-like that at first glance she didn't seem to be real. But JonBenét Ramsey's face is the kind that sticks in your mind. She was a radiant, beautiful child — that's one reason people still remember her. Another one: her tragic murder, which has remained unsolved for nearly 20 years. Conspiracy theorists, not to mention actual detectives, are still stuck on decoding clues that would finally break her case. Now, a video making the rounds suggests that JonBenét has been alive all along — and living her life undercover as the singer Katy Perry, no less. The theory is not only insane, it's highly offensive to the Ramsey family after everything they've been through. In 2014, YouTube user Dave Johnson  in which he claims, via voice-over, that Ramsey is living undercover as Katy Perry. "Nobody died, nobody got hurt. That sacrifice was in name only, and that was to get something, and that something was to become a star," he says. "JonBenét became Katy Perry, and that’s a fact.” The video suggests that Perry's parents are actually Patsy and John Ramsey in disguise as Keith Hudson and Mary Perry. "He shaved his head. She lost some weight," Johnson explains, as though that's enough evidence to prove that four distinct people are, in actuality, two skillful pretenders who have been keeping up a decades-long charade. (Patsy Ramsey, a former beauty queen herself, died in 2006; her ex-husband, John, has since remarried. Katy Perry's parents are both alive and  in their daughter's life.) The problem here isn't Johnson's proof or lack thereof: The video is inarguably invalid, and no one is entertaining the idea that there's any truth to it. What's fucked up is that — _even though we all know there isn't a kernel of truth in the theory_ — it's still making the rounds on the internet, where people are suddenly comparing a dead child's features with those of a 31-year-old pop singer.

It details the claims made, how the conspiracy is framed as a narrative, and the implications for the Ramsey family. This makes it highly relevant to understanding both origins and promotion.

Reasonable conspiracy theory claims that Katy Perry is JonBénet Ramsey
======================================================================
A rising YouTube conspiracy theory claims that the famous singer is actually the deceased child model.
By   on February 26, 2016
") ") ")
!
* * *
Everyone thought JonBénet Ramsey was dead -- but one random man on YouTube begs to differ.
In a video, published in 2014 but gone viral in the past 24 hours, ") poses a powerful theory. Pop sensation Katy Perry isn't who you think she is, Johnson claims. She's actually just the adult version of the infamous, presumably dead, child model.

Johnson claims that Ramsey's parents staged her death so that she could grow up to become a star. Why they'd need to do that, or how that was even possible, is completely irrelevant. If you don't have faith in Johnson's theory, your fate is sealed and doomed.
!
"JonBénet Ramsey became "). That’s a fact,” Johnson continued. “So if any of you continue to lie about this person dying, you are a false witness to murder. That’s a fact."
Johnson grounds his theory in several very subtle pieces of evidence:
*   The family's faces appear to be the same (just look at the mashup)
*   There was a strong financial motive involved
*   Anyone who disagrees with him is a "false death liar" who is going to "burn... for it."
Katy Perry (or JonBénet?) seems to have already responded to the accusation in her song "Dark Horse (Remix)": "No worry about where I'm from, Just...[Content truncated]

Query1.title: Katy Perry Is JonBenét Ramsey? Here's Your Guide to the Online ...
Query1.snippet: Feb 26, 2016 ... The internet is a wealth of conspiracy theories. Some of them are backed by celebrities: Christine Ebersole, for instance, believes that 9/11 ...

content.content:
Katy Perry and JonBenét Ramsey (Photos: Getty Images/Splash News)
The internet is a wealth of conspiracy theories. Some of them are backed by celebrities: Christine Ebersole, for instance, believes that 9/11 was an inside job, and Kylie Jenner is pretty certain our government is trying to poison us using commercial airliners. And then some involve celebrities themselves: Beyoncé thinks all her haters are corny with that Illuminati mess and, thanks to the work of the Daily Dot’s Rick Paulas, the latest great celebrity conspiracy theory is that Katy Perry is JonBenét Ramsey all grown up.
Let’s start with the background. JonBenét Ramsey was born August 6, 1990, in Atlanta, Georgia. The day after Christmas 1996, Ramsay’s body was found in her parents’ basement in Boulder, Colorado; she had been strangled to death. Her killer was never caught. That is, unless, she never really died at all, adopted a new identity, and became global superstar Katy Perry.
There is a relatively small but incredibly dedicated community on YouTube devoted to proving conspiracies of various and increasingly obvious fictionality. One of those is that rather than die at age 6, JonBenét became Katy Perry. The why of the matter isn’t really so important but it has something to...[Content truncated]

Its reliability depends heavily on the sources it cites. While it has sections that include reputable news coverage, it is also known for less rigorous journalism, particularly in entertainment topics.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides more background on the situation, explaining the details of JonBenét's murder and introducing a YouTube community that promotes the theory. It emphasizes the lack of credible evidence and the motivations behind the conspiracy theories, which is essential for understanding the origins of the claim.

Hot New Conspiracy Theory: Katy Perry Is Actually JonBenet Ramsey
=================================================================
But where does Ted Cruz fit in?
By Published: Feb 26, 2016 1:35 PM EST
!Save Article
!
You probably followed the highly publicized investigation into the tragic murder of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey, a case that was never solved. You probably have your own opinions as to what happened, or who left the alleged ransom letter. But, have you ever once entertained the possibility that Ramsey is not dead, and that she grew up to be multi-platinum pop superstar Katy Perry?
Consider the many facts from master YouTube detective Dave Johnson:
\- Overlapping photos of Katy Perry and JonBenet Ramsey look like overlapping photos of Katy Perry and JonBenet Ramsey.
\- Overlapping photos of JonBenet Ramsey's parents and Katy Perry's parents look like overlapping photos of Katy Perry and JonBenet Ramsey's parents.
He explains these two facts in a very thorough 7-minute video. And if you don't believe in this very clear cut explanation, you are "a false witness to murder and death." Nevermind the fact that Katy Perry was born in 1984, six years before Ramsey. But how does this explain ?
And just think, this time last week we were talking about .

Is Katy Perry Really JonBenet Ramsey?
=====================================
] February 26, 2016 / 12:02 PM EST / CBS Miami
*   
*   
*   
**Follow CBSMIAMI.COM:**  **|** 
MIAMI (CBSMiami) -- A conspiracy theory has resurfaced surrounding the unsolved murder of  young beauty pageant princess JonBenet Ramsey.
In a resurfaced YouTube video from December 2014, a man named Dave Johnson claims that Ramsey is not dead but is really pop princess Katy Perry.
Ramsey was murdered in 1996.
Johnson, who does not show his face in the video, claims the family kept this secret so that Perry could rise to fame and become a super star.
JonBenet's murder remains unsolved.
What do you think?
### More from CBS News
 Man accused of throwing dog at police officer]

Query2.title: The Craziest Celebrity Conspiracy Theories
Query2.snippet: May 27, 2023 ... 1. Tupac Shakur faked his death · 2. Katy Perry is JonBenet Ramsey · 3. Britney Spears is a clone · 4. Keanu Reeves is immortal · 5. Church of ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]...Benet's parents faked her death and that she then went on to live her life as Katy Perry.
Supporters of this theory point to similarities in their appearance and suggest that this was all part of an elaborate cover-up. However, there is no evidence to support this theory and it remains just that - a theory.
Britney Spears quickly became a household name with her rise to fame in the late 90's. However, some people believe that the Britney we see today is not the original. Instead, they claimed that she was a Brittany Spears clone following her breakdown in 2007.
Supporters of the theory point to changes in her appearance, her behavior, and the fact that she has not been seen in public for extended periods of time. While this theory may seem far-fetched, it continues to be a topic of conversation among conspiracy theorists.
Check out these 5 Powerful Documentaries About Britney Spears
Keanu Reeves has been a Hollywood staple for over three decades, but some people believe that the actor isn't just talented - he's also immortal. The theory suggests that Reeves is a part of a secret society that has existed for centuries and that he has been photographed in various historical events throughout time.
Supporters of this theory point to the fact that Reeves hasn't aged much over the years and that his characters often have similarities in their appearance. While it's unlikely that Reeves is immortal, this theory is certainly an interesting one.
One of the craziest conspiracy theories circulating around Hollywood is that the Church of Scientology held auditions to find Tom Cruise's next wife.
The theory suggests that the church wanted someone who would be a good public face for the religion and that the "winning" candidate would have the opportunity to marry Cruise. The church has denied these claims, but the theory still persists.
Check out these 13 Shocking Documentaries About Scientology
One of the most popular celebrity conspiracy theories is that the moon landing was faked. The theory suggests that the government could not successfully accomplish the moon landing, so they hired the famous film director Stanley Kubrick to fake it.
The theory goes on to claim that Kubrick included secret messages in his films to reveal the truth. While there is no evidence to support this theory, it continues to be a topic of debate among conspiracy theorists.
Check out our podcast episode on Wonderful: Stories From the Space Station

QA.Question: What are the origins of the conspiracy theory linking Katy Perry to JonBenét Ramsey and who promotes it?
QA.Answer: The conspiracy theory linking Katy Perry to JonBenét Ramsey originated largely from a viral YouTube video created by a user named Dave Johnson, published in 2014. In this video, Johnson claims that JonBenét Ramsey, who was murdered in 1996, did not actually die but instead grew up to become Katy Perry, suggesting that her death was staged to allow her to live under a different identity. This theory has been circulated and perpetuated by conspiracy theorists who buy into his argument without any credible backing. The theory gained significant media attention around February 2016 when it became a topic of discussion across various platforms. Articles highlight that this speculation is not only unfounded but also highly offensive to the Ramsey family, who have endured the tragedy of their daughter’s murder and the subsequent scrutiny it attracted. The supporters of this theory often point to supposed similarities in appearances or family backgrounds, but these claims lack tangible evidence and are based on superficial comparisons rather than substantive proof. In essence, this conspiracy theory is propagated by a mix of dubious online content and anecdotal comparisons rather than credible investigative journalism or factual evidence. The idea has become a part of internet folklore, despite being dismissed by reputable sources.
